title: ISic003354. I.Sicily inscription 003354
body:
1[C(aio)] [Vallio ---] Quir(ina) Postum[o patro]no [mu]nicipii
2[flam(ini) divi H]adriani perpetuo [in] quinq(ue) decur(ias) iudi-
3[cum inter] quadringenarios adlecto a divo Anto-
4[nino Au]g(usto) Pio omnib(us) honorib(us) civitatis suae ho-
5[nestissi]me functo item legatione gratuita apud
6[divum] Hadrianum et apud amplissimum ordinem de
7[vectig]alib(us) redhibendis pleps Gaulitana ex aere con-
8[lato o]b plura merita eius #leaf d(ecreto) d(ecurionum) #leaf

l.7 reg., orig. pleps

1[........---]QUIRPOSTUM[......]NO[..]NICIPII
2[.........]ADRIANIPERPETUO[..]QUINQDECURIUDI
3[........]QUADRINGENARIOSADLECTOADIVOANTO
4[......]GPIOOMNIBHONORIBCIVITATISSUAEHO
5[........]MEFUNCTOITEMLEGATIONEGRATUITAAPUD
6[.....]HADRIANUMETAPUDAMPLISSIMUMORDINEMDE
7[......]ALIBREDHIBENDISPLEPSGAULITANAEXAERECON
8[.....]BPLURAMERITAEIUS(leaf)DD(leaf)

l.7 reg., orig. pleps

Facsimile Images

Apparatus criticus

  • Photographs and Pirino

English translation

Alex Antoniou

To Caius Vallius Postumus [son ?], of tribe Quirina, patron of the municipium, perpetual flamen of Divus Hadrian, raised to the rank of quadringenarius amongst the five decuria of judges by the divine Antoninus Augustus Pius, having most honourably held all the honours of a citizen of his own town, as well as having at his own expense served as legate both to the deified Hadrian and the Senate regarding the repayment of taxes, the plebs Gaulita [set this up] by public subscription on account of his many merits and by decree of the decuriones

commentary

bibliography

  • 10.7507 & p.994 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10000589
  • 2006.0518 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001283
  • 6772 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10000352
  • Christol and Pirino 2006 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001367

English translation

Alex Antoniou

To Caius Vallius Postumus [son ?], of tribe Quirina, patron of the municipium, perpetual flamen of Divus Hadrian, raised to the rank of quadringenarius amongst the five decuria of judges by the divine Antoninus Augustus Pius, having most honourably held all the honours of a citizen of his own town, as well as having at his own expense served as legate both to the deified Hadrian and the Senate regarding the repayment of taxes, the plebs Gaulita [set this up] by public subscription on account of his many merits and by decree of the decuriones
